THE PROPOSAL 

1. 
I  submit  for  your  approval  the  following  report  and  recommendation  on  a  proposed 
equity investment of up to $30 million in CNY equivalent (or, if ADB is unable to fund in CNY, in

II. 

BACKGROUND AND RATIONALE 

A. 

PRC Economic Development and Industry Background  

1. 

Overview of Latest Developments in the PRC Economy 

In recent years, the PRC has made progress in restructuring its economy, especially by 
2. 
reducing its dependence on Government spending and increasing the performance of its state-
owned enterprise (SOE) sector. On the surface, the PRC possesses a respectable credit profile 
(Standard & Poors: A-, Moody’s: A2, Fitch: A-). The economy features rapid growth rates, high 
savings and investment rates, low Government and external debt, and stable long-term capital 
inflows.  Driven  by  buoyant  domestic  investment  and  exports,  gross  domestic  product  (GDP) 
growth has exceeded 9% for 4 straight years, including 9.9% in 2005. The PRC’s key strength, 
however, lies in its strong external balance. The current account surplus is about three times the 
countries external debt, while reserves cover its external debt three times and short-term debt 
five  times.  The  economic  expansion  continued  in  the  first  quarter  of  2006,  as  real  GDP  grew 
10.2%  compared  with  the  same  period  in  2005—much  faster  than  the  Government’s  full-year 
projection of 8% growth. Investment and exports continued to propel growth in the first quarter. 
Exports  increased  26.6%  year-on-year,  helping  to  boost  official  foreign  exchange  reserves  to 
$875  billion at  the  end of  March  from  $819  billion  3  months  earlier.  Yet  economic reforms,  as 
well as social and environmental issues, will continue to present challenges for the foreseeable 
future. An economic summary of the PRC is in Appendix 1. 
 

2.  Small and Medium-Sized Enterprises in the PRC: Driving Growth 

 
Small and medium-sized enterprises (SME)1 play a significant role in the PRC economy, 
3. 
driving employment, economic growth, and development. They account for almost half of GDP, 
two  thirds  of  industrial  value  added,  60%  of  exports,  and  40%  of  fiscal  revenues.2 SMEs  also 
provide 75% of urban and rural employment. Private sector SMEs have grown faster than the 
larger  SOEs.  In  recent  years,  the  industrial  output  of  SMEs  has  been  increasing  at an  annual 
average  rate  of  30%,  compared  with  20%  for  industry  as  a  whole. 3  Consequently,  the 
development of the SME sector is regarded as more than an important engine of growth. It is 
considered a key contributor to poverty reduction by generating jobs, individual income, and tax 
revenues. 
 
4. 
SMEs rely heavily on access to external capital to finance their operations. However, a 
survey  by  the  State  Information  Center  found  that  more  than  80%  of  the  PRC’s  SMEs  have 
difficulty accessing financial services and securing financing.4 Although bank loans in the PRC

3. 

Overview of the PRC Financial System  

5. 
The  banking  sector  plays  a  dominant  role  in  the  PRC’s  financial system.  At  the  end  of 
September  2005,  the  PRC’s  commercial  banking  system  comprised  (i)  four  national  state-
owned commercial banks (SOCB), (ii) 13 national joint-stock commercial banks (JSCB), (iii) 112 
city  commercial  banks  (CCB),  (iv)  57  rural  cooperative  and  commercial  banks,  (v)  626  urban 
credit cooperatives, (vi) about 30,000 rural credit cooperatives, and (vii) 238 operational entities 
of foreign banks.5 The four SOCBs dominate the sector, together accounting for 54% of banking 
sector assets, followed by the JSCBs (15%), and the CCBs (5%) (Table 1; Appendix 2, Figure 
A2.1). Foreign banks account for less than 2% of market share.

In  the  PRC,  the  ratio  of  bank  assets  to  stock  market  capitalization  plus  bonds 
outstanding  exceeds  300%,  a  far  higher  ratio  than  in  most  industrialized  countries  and  even

States  have  ratios  less  than  100%.  The  high  relative  importance  of  the  banking  sector  is 
common in many developing economies. In the PRC, however, it is particularly important due to 
the  large  market  size  and  fast  growth.  The  PRC’s  financial  institution  assets  have  grown  at  a 
compounded annual growth rate (CAGR) of 13% since 2000, reaching $4.9 trillion at the end of 
March  2006—about  the  same  as  the  United  Kingdom’s  financial  sector  (Appendix  2,  Figure 
A2.2). 
 
7. 
The banking sector is at the center of the Government’s economic reforms. Measures to 
clean up the banks have improved asset quality and capitalization, and in many instances risk 
management.  However,  uncertainties  over  the  quality  of  banks’  assets  remain.  In  addition, 
limited  foreign  participation  in  the  sector  and  cultural  resistance  to  foreign  influence  might 
constrain the pace of reforms. The recapitalization costs for the banking system are a moving 
target,  and  one  of  the  major  risk  factors  constraining  the  PRC’s  credit  profile  and  future

B. 

City Commercial Banks in the PRC Banking Sector 

1. 

Overview  

8. 
The  CCBs  were  formed  through  Government-directed  amalgamations  of  urban  credit 
cooperatives  (UCC)  in  the  mid  to  late  1990s.  This  amalgamation  was  partly  a  response  to 
galloping  NPLs  created  by  the  unsustainable  UCCs,  and  partly  an  effort  to  consolidate  the 
financial  sector  to  achieve  economies  of  scale.  During  this  process,  however,  the  CCBs 
received  full  financial  and  managerial  support  by  their  respective  city  governments.  Moreover, 
only  one  CCB  was  created  in  each  city  (i.e.,  no  competition  for  Government  favors).  Thus, 
CCBs  remained  a  de  facto  part  of  the  city  governments’  economic  planning  apparatus.  This 
included significant directed lending to government priority projects and SOEs.  
 
Typically,  CCBs  still  maintain  very  strong  ties  to  their  respective  city  governments.  In 
9. 
many  cities,  the  respective  governments  still  hold  majority  equity  stakes.  Some  progressive 
CCBs have  diversified shareholdings, which include local private and state-owned companies, 
as  well  as  upgraded  employees  with  increasing  commercial  skills.  However,  few  CCBs  have 
substantial private investment, and none is listed on any stock exchange.  
 
10. 
Although  CCBs  play  an  important  role  in  their  respective  local  banking  sectors,  their 
contribution  to  the  PRC’s  financial  sector  is  still  relatively  small.  Together,  the  112  CCBs 
account  for  slightly  more  than  5%  of  the  PRC  banking  sector’s  assets.  Although  small  by 
comparison to other banks in the PRC, CCBs serve cities that can be very large—as large as 
small countries in some cases. For example, Bank of Beijing, Bank of Shanghai, and Chongqing 
City  Commercial  Bank all  operate  in  markets  with  populations  of  more  than  10  million.  Tianjin 
has a population of 7.6 million, while Hangzhou has 3.9 million people.  
 
11. 
At  the  end  of  March  2006,  CCB  assets  totaled  CNY2.1  trillion,  while  CCB  equity  was 
CNY83.2 billion, according to CBRC. The average CCB NPL ratio was 7.6% at the end of March 
2006, compared with an average of 8.0% for the entire banking sector. In many cities, however, 
the NPL ratio is still above 20%. As of March 2006, the weighted average capital adequacy ratio 
for  the  CCB  subsector  had  increased  significantly  to  more  than  5%,  but  remained  below  the 
required 8%. 
 

2. 

Issues Facing CCBs and Policy Reform Initiatives 

12. 
The CCBs have the potential to continue growing at a healthy rate in line with the PRC’s 
economy  and  banking  sector.  One  forecaster  anticipates  CCBs  will  grow  at  a  CAGR  of  26%, 
reaching nearly $656 billion in assets by 2009.7  
 
13. 
However,  most  CCBs  will  have  difficulty  sustaining  growth  rates  without  jeopardizing 
asset  quality  and  capital  adequacy.  To  provide  competitive,  customer-driven  services  and 
products targeted at underserved segments of the markets in cities and regions of the PRC, the 
CCBs will have to develop their capabilities quickly to match those of a modern banking sector.

In this process, the CCBs will have to address some key issues, including (i) limited access to 
state-of-the-art banking technology and know-how, (ii) lack of economies of scale in funding, (iii) 
undercapitalization  and  high  levels  of  NPLs,  (iv)  a  legacy  of  government  influence  in  strategic 
focus and in management, (v) lack of competitive experience due to the favored position in the 
respective  city,  (vi)  a  history  of  deficient  corporate  governance  and  internal  controls,  and  (vii) 
limited growth prospects within each respective city. 
 
14. 
To address these issues, several logical evolutionary steps are needed for this sector: (i) 
tie-ups  with  (foreign)  strategic  partners  that  can  bring  operational  know-how,  a  competitive 
mindset, better governance, and capital; (ii) sales of significant equity stakes to nongovernment 
entities to dilute the influence of, and reliance on, the local government; (iii) cessation of further 
Government support to undercapitalized banks that are unable to meet CBRC capital adequacy 
requirements  by  the  prescribed  deadlines;  (iv)  opening  up  of  cities  to  competition  from  other 
CCBs (initially from the same province, but eventually CCBs from any part of the country); and 
(v)  consolidation  of  CCBs  into  fewer,  stronger  banks  that  are  more  capable  of  exploring 
economies of scale. 
 
15. 
The  CBRC  has  outlined  a  four-point  reform  strategy  to  enhance  the  development  and 
supervision of CCBs:8 (i) CCBs should define clear market strategies to focus on local residents 
and SMEs, playing to their inherent competitive advantages; (ii) CCBs should resolve impaired 
assets  through  close  cooperation  with  local  governments  and  other  means,  such  as  asset 
swaps  and  the  introduction  of  qualified  strategic  investors;  (iii)  CCBs  should  improve  their 
corporate  governance  structure  and  mechanisms;  and  (iv)  the  CBRC  will  adopt  differentiated 
policies and approaches in supervising different categories of CCBs, allowing a larger scope of 
operations for CCBs with sound management and good business performance, while preparing 
a  “market  exit”  for  CCBs  with  high  risks.  Accordingly,  the  CBRC  approved  the  first  cross-city 
expansion,  allowing  Bank  of  Shanghai  to  set  up  a  branch  in  Ningbo.  Further,  six  CCBs  and 
seven  UCCs  in  Anhui  Province  were  restructured  recently  into  Huishang  Bank—the  first 
regional commercial bank in the PRC created from the restructuring of local financial institutions 
within one province. 
 

3. 

CCBs as Investment Opportunities 

16. 
Several international financial institutions have invested in PRC commercial banks, using 
their  investments  as  a  tool  to  understand  the  country’s  banking  industry  and  accumulate 
operating  experience.  However,  the  integration  of  the  PRC  banking  industry  into  the 
international market is in its infancy. In light of the huge opportunities in the PRC market, foreign 
banks  are  facing  the  challenge  of  how  to  formulate  and  implement  their  PRC  development 
strategies. With the overwhelming size and limited availability of the SOCBs, foreign banks are 
looking at JSCBs and CCBs as appropriate investments for entry into the PRC banking sector. 
 
17. 
The  economic  profile  of  the  city  where  a  bank  is  located  largely  determines  the 
commercial  attractiveness  of  an  investment  in  a  CCB.  Generally,  this  is  a  function  of  the 
population  size,  economic  growth  prospects,  and  investment  climate.  In  addition,  the  targeted 
bank  must  have  acceptable  asset  quality,  market  position,  and  management  willing  to 
implement  changes.  Forbes  magazine  ranked  the  PRC  cities  with  the  best  investment 
environments:  Hangzhou,  Guangzhou,  Shanghai,  and  Shenzhen.  It  also  ranked  the  top  ten

18. 
Not all of the 112 CCBs will be able to attract quality strategic partners, however. Thus, 
in  the  medium  to  long  run,  only  a  handful  is  expected  to  lead  the  consolidation  and  market 
expansion efforts. The Private Sector Operations Division (PSOP) of ADB believes that only the 
top 15–20 CCBs will find suitable strategic investors, and 30–40 at most will survive in the long 
term.  In  line  with  this  assessment,  the  Government  appears  prepared  to  take  a  hard  stance 
against  supporting  CCBs  operating  with  high  risks,  including  contemplating  closure. 11  The 
survivors will be the ones willing to change. To increase long-term viability and attractiveness to

1. 

Investment Rationale 

 
34. 
An  efficient  financial  system  promotes  sustainable  economic  growth,  which  generates 
employment  and  reduces  poverty.  Financial  intermediation,  particularly  through  the  banking 
sector,  is  the  main  engine  for  economic  growth.  The  banking  sector  dominates  the  financial 
system  in  the  PRC.  However,  the  inefficiency  of  the  sector  has  been  identified  as  one  of  the 
greatest  obstacles  to  long-term  growth,  especially  with  regard  to  SMEs.  (Appendix  1). 
Recognizing  the  need  to  improve  the  banking  sector,  the  Government  has  encouraged  its 
banks, especially SOCBs, to undergo reform. For certain qualified banks, the Government has 
promoted the involvement of private domestic and foreign strategic investors. The first stage of 
reforms targeted the “big four” SOCBs. Now the focus of reforms is on the network of 112 CCBs 
that  serve  major  urban  areas  throughout  the  PRC.  These  CCBs  play—and  will  continue  to 
play—a vital role in and around the cities they serve, especially in SME development. However, 
CCBs will have to address some significant issues before they can improve, including strategic 
risk, poor corporate governance, weak risk management, and low capital adequacy ratios. The 
success of the PRC’s banking reforms, SME development, and economic growth hinges on the 
ability of the PRC banks, especially the CCBs, to address these challenges properly. 
 
35. 
CBRC  views  the  introduction  of  experienced  and  qualified  overseas  strategic  investors 
as an effective method to promote and enhance this reform process.17 On the micro level, the 
sale  of  strategic  stakes  in  these  banks  boosts  capital,  dilutes  government  influence,  provides 
access  to  strategic  and  operational  know-how,  and  brings  better  corporate  governance.  The 
enhanced strategic focus and increased capital also will help the bank become more prepared 
for  competition  in  its  home  market.  Further,  this  will  enable  the  bank  to  take  advantage  of 
growth  opportunities  in  new  markets  via  acquisitions,  mergers,  or  strategic  cooperation  with 
banks  in  other  cities  and  provinces;  or  via  greenfield  organic  establishment  in  such  markets. 
However,  while  the  growth  prospects  of  the  PRC’s  banking  sector  are  attractive  to  investors, 
international banks remain wary of taking minority stakes even in relatively higher-quality CCBs.

potential  inability  as  minority  investor  to  influence  strategic  direction,  management,  and  equity 
distributions; and (iii) uncertainty over the continued role of local government.

countries  in  the  region.  The  lack  of  a  consistent  nationwide  credit  database  impedes  lending

The top four state-owned banks—the ICBC, the Bank of China, the Agriculture Bank of China 
and the China Construction Bank—all have actually started preparing to implement Basel II and 
plan to invest heavily on IT infrastructure to meet Basel II requirements.

Corporate Lending and Growing Demand for Retail Banking Products 

2. 
 
15. 
Corporate banking will remain the primary focus of the PRC banking industry in the near 
to midterm future, because of the sheer demand and growth potential. PRC corporations are the 
growth engine of the country’s economic development. In the past, a large majority of loans by 
PRC financial institutions have been made to SOEs, a trend which will change as privatizations 
increase.  In  addition,  newly  founded  privately-owned  corporations  are  becoming  increasingly 
important borrowers.  
 
16. 
As the PRC banking industry has liberalized, banking institutions have been allowed to 
offer consumer lending products. Rising incomes are likely to foster growing consumer demand 
for banking products and services. It is anticipated that retail banking will continue to grow, with 
increasing demands for mortgages and other consumer loans. According to the National Bureau 
of Statistics, consumer loans in the PRC totaled CNY2.0 trillion in 2004, representing 10.5% of 
total loans and 14.6% of GDP, and grew at a compound annual growth rate of 36.5% from 2002 
to 2004. 
 
17.  Mortgage  loans  represented  the  majority  of  overall  consumer  loans  in  2003,  and  were 
fueled  by  the  Government’s  efforts  to  reform  the  housing  system,  under  which  employees  of 
SOEs previously received free or subsidized housing. Mortgage loans have grown rapidly from 
CNY609.9  billion  in  2001  to  over  CNY1.2  trillion  in  2003,  according  to  the  Ministry  of 
Construction. 
 
18. 
The  vast  majority  of  bank  cards  in  the  PRC  are  debit  cards.  There  are  approximately 
517,000  credit  and  points-of-sale  and  67,000  automated  teller  machines  (ATMs)  in  the  PRC. 
The  credit  card  market  has  so  far  been  limited  for  a  variety  of  reasons,  including  the  limited 
acceptance of cards by merchants, the underdevelopment of a national payment infrastructure, 
and  the  absence  of  a  nationwide  consumer  credit  information  system.  According  to  the  PRC 
Unionpay, an electronic interbank information exchange and transaction network, at the end of 
2004,  815  million  banking  cards  had  been  issued  in  the  PRC,  only  11  million  of  which  were 
credit cards.
